body:
@jacques-n, Would you mind helping see if the latest patch is acceptable?

thanks

+1 overall, there are 2 places where @amansinha100 could give his opinion about

can we add a unit test too ?

lgtm.

Do you want to add a unit test that verifies the buffer reader index == zero behavior in addition to the integration-ish test you added?
Add a unit test to ensure that, in DrillBuf, readIndex is reset (pointing at 0) for both clear and !clear cases.
A few small comments. Otherwise, looks good. Thanks for the updates!
lgtm +1
Can we keep this but change to -DskipTests to verify compilation?
updated to turn off tests instead
@sudheeshkatkam can you please review ? thx
This was merged into the 1.3 release branch, but I just realized it was not merged into master. Will get it in shortly.
Fixed in a5a1aa6b487d0642641ce70f2c2500465956f9ec
I ran the full test suite. It's green
@jaltekruse did you mean to merge this?
travis-ci is green: mvn package -DskipTests=true
Thanks @sudheeshkatkam. Did you mean to commit this?
Thanks @jaltekruse ! Did you mean to commit this?
I put it on my merge branch but it actually caused two small compilation issues in other modules that were using the utility method you refactored. I forgot to update this with a comment.
Thanks for the heads up. I will fix this.
Other than the minor comment, lgtm. +1
@jaltekruse should be better now :)

This looks great!
I made some comments above.

Updated the patch. @StevenMPhillips, @jacques-n, if you guys can do a quick review. 
The cache code now uses the same file name and reads the metadata appropriately. Note that as a result, v1 and v2 of the cache file can not co-exist (and also means that Drill 1.3 and earlier are no longer forward compatible).
+1 LGTM

Overall looks great. 
Note on performance and concurrency numbers : 
 Dechang ran the performance and concurrency tests and we see no performance regressions. Numbers are almost the same. Concurrency seems to have improved. We see some failures when running 96 concurrent tpch-query6, that may be due to other resource constraints. No deadlocks.
@vkorukanti , the patches pass the unit test, pre-commit test, and impersonation test.
Thank you!

I didn't do a full build with tests before merging, and it looks like there is a checkstyle problem.
I fixed it, and am now doing a full build to verify before merging.
As long as you are changing it do you want to remove the two test classes still using this method and then just delete it?
Which method?

merged in 
https://github.com/apache/drill/commit/b45e966f0a3067e1f8dda5ad106d2c3ac41d6019
https://github.com/apache/drill/commit/e138bb984e1778f6ed3d3335523a323e483bab8f
The one that is generating a string representation of the result set, which caused the bug. getResultString()
@vkorukanti , could you please take a look at the revised patch?

This should not be using the File.Separator, as it is working with Hadoop and will always get Unix paths, even when running on Windows. Please see the JIRA linked below.

https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/DRILL-3107
Thanks for the pointer. For some reason, I had this impression that File.separator relies on underlying FS and not the native one. I will revert.

One other point here, the issue with fully qualified names actually shouldn't be a problem in the usual usage of this function. The function was only designed to be evaluated at planning time with the interpreter, not with the full code compilation model in the project operator. While not ideal, the expected error that should be hit if this function is used in a select list is here in the FragmentContext when we go to populate the injected PartitionExplorer. https://github.com/apache/drill/blob/master/exec/java-exec/src/main/java/org/apache/drill/exec/ops/FragmentContext.java#L458

Has there been work to make partition pruning run the full code generation based expression evaluation? I would consider anyone hitting code generation issues with this function to be misusing it, I agree with fixing this poor error, but anyone executing this function outside of partition pruning is going to be running a very expensive operation for each record in their dataset and I can't think of a use case for it.

Yeah, I am aware of the thrown warning. However, note that in the lieu of this fix user faces a compilation exception before the warning is shown when explorers are used in projection. Also, I definitely see a good use case for projecting the outcome of explorers like inspecting partition pruning. This patch has no means to address these though.

Apologies, didn't think about the order in which compilation and resolving the injectables would be executed. I thought I had verified that this error would make it back to users if the function was used in a select list, but obviously there wasn't a test for it.

As far as looking at the output of explorers, the easiest way to do this would be to use a function like maxdir in the where clause and then just include dirN in the select clause as well. This will cause the function to be evaluated just during pruning.

`select dir0 from dfs.workspace`path/to/dir/*` where dir0 = MAXDIR('dfs.workspace', '/path/to/dir');`
Have some minor comments on the DRILL-4127. LGTM, +1.
Cool. This reminds me, I should add a test now :) Thanks for the projection example.
Address venki's comments in the revised patches.
Fixed: https://drill.apache.org/docs/tutorial-develop-a-simple-function/#add-a-drill-module-conf-file-to-resources

I left some comments that should be easy fixes, other than that LGTM
+1
@jinfengni Could you please review the patch?
+1. LGTM.
+1 for the DRILL-4194 patch.
Bridget added a new section https://drill.apache.org/docs/plugin-configuration-basics/#using-the-formats-attributes-as-table-function-parameters to cover this PR. Thanks, Julien.

@julienledem, @adeneche and @parthchandra: I've updated the patch to address the review comments as well as the close/transfer race condition. For easy of consumption and tracking, I've avoided rebasing. Once I get confirmation that the updates look good, I get it ready for final merge.

ec25614 passes unit and extended regression suite.

I also rebased the branch on the latest master. Testing it now. Can be seen here:
https://github.com/jacques-n/drill/commits/DRILL-4134v2
@amansinha100 , could you please review the patch for DRILL-4201? Thanks!
can we add a unit test ? thanks
@StevenMPhillips Can you review this change?
The test file for this is 600MB which is too large for a unit test. I would recommend we add this to the regression test suite.

+1, LGTM

We should try and add a test to the public test framework, once this PR is merged
+1 LGTM.
@StevenMPhillips yup makes sense, should we do that under another JIRA?
Resolved as part of DRILL-2288 patch.
@hnfgns updated PR based on your review comments.

Results of the performance test are good, no regressions.
Only one comment left to address (peakAllocation computation), but other than that:
+1
Shoot, I mistyped my close message. Should have been 283 instead of 238. @nagix, can you reopen this pull request?
Rebased and merged in 809f4620d7d82c72240212de13b993049550959d
@jacques-n, I don't believe I can re-open this because I didn't close it. Can you do it or do l need to open a new request?

Maybe just submit new request. I can't reopen either.
On Dec 22, 2015 7:30 AM, "Akihiko Kusanagi" notifications@github.com
wrote:

> @jacques-n https://github.com/jacques-n, I don't believe I can re-open
> this because I didn't close it. Can you do it or do l need to open a new
> request?
> 
> 
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/apache/drill/pull/238#issuecomment-166647086.
Submitted a new request #309
@sudheeshkatkam please review
How should cancellation be handled when the query is ENQUEUED?
Cancellation is handled usual way after query is cancelled only after it has been started.
Addressed review comments.

Yes. cancellation remains the same, but it would be nice to be able to cancel when the state is ENQUEUED (interrupt the thread waiting on the semaphore).

+1

@StevenMPhillips , let me know your thoughts. 

To others interested, this doesn't modify any existing code paths so has no impact on existing workloads.

+1

As long as this doesn't break the build, I say we go ahead and merge it. We can add tests and fixes later.
I published the fix (cannot merge pull requests). Thanks.
I agree with Steven, at the hackathon we already did some basic performance and correctness verification at reasonable scale. +1
I am unfamiliar with the code so I won't be able to review, but can you please add error messages to the assertions, it will make our lives much more easier if we need to debug them. Thanks
+1 LGTM
Thanks @StevenMPhillips , I will squash the commits, run one final round of tests and commit to master
@amansinha100 can you please review ? thanks
@StevenMPhillips, can you close?
@nategri, can you close?

The purpose of this PR is to separate the functions that support the FRAME clause in CustomFrameTemplate from the ones that don't in DefaultFrameTemplate. Work still needs to be done to make the refactoring complete (like making sure code is not duplicated between the templates), but I decided to leave it after I make the necessary changes to support the FRAME clause.

@amansinha100 can you please review ?
Passes unit and regression suites

I changed the merging receiver so it no longer waits for the last batch when it's an early termination. Unit tests and regression tests are all passing.

@amansinha100 can you please review ?
+1 .   For functional testing we should try to have a similar scenario with skew in the data for the build side of the HashJoin such that some minor fragments get 0 rows.

Overall refactoring looks ok.  One thing that needs some clarity: Is the definition of default frame 'between unbounded preceding and current row' ?  If the user explicitly specifies this frame in the query, will it be treated as default or custom frame  (as opposed to not specifying anything frame) ?
